reviews.review_text: Miner Wars 2081 promises epic space battles, but instead gives you a frustrating game of resource micro-management. Every amenity on your ship - from ammunition to oxygen to fuel - is limited, and runs out rather quickly. Even if the vast, bland environments were actually worth looking around, the game simply wouldn't allow you any exploration due to your limited resources. When you finally actually do get to fighting, the balance is atrocious, with some enemies barely leaving a scratch on your hull, while others in the same area annihilate you as soon as you get in range.  I was hoping for a spiritual successor to the Descent/Freespace series, as those remain among my favorites of all time, but sadly this is nowhere near pulling it off. Stay far, far away.

Miner Wars is a shoddy, half-done mess whose developer realised at some point in development that they couldn't deliver on any of their promises, and rather than doing right by their community, decided to cut and run by shoehorning in a half-baked story campaign and calling it a finished product. That they still dare to refer to it as open-world is a farce. Avoid, and be wary of the developer's other products.

This review is long overdue for a game I consider to be worth the $4 bucks it's on sale for now. Dear reader, you've probably seen the overwhelming negative reviews for this game. Take the time to read mine. Let's talk about positives.   * If you like 6DOF like Descent, or some of its clones this game does the job nicely.  * Environments are fully destructible (this can be in issue on some missions, like if there's a terminal checkpoint you have to access but it's been blown away)  * Weapons for the most part are ballistic, and energy based weapons like lasers are non-existent.  * Levels are 'sandbox' in nature. One example I'd use is, you can attack an asteroid base through the front door with all kinds of defense turrents coming at you... Or you can fly to the other side and blast through the asteroid, and knock out the power generator from the back disabling all the turrents. * Very cool game engine. Graphics are pretty tight, sound is good, levels are big. I don’t have crashes on my hardware Voice acting is top notch. We have to do some focus here. Steve Blum, Beau Billingslea, Wendee Lee  Most people aren't going to know these names unless they're super Otaku and into anime. It's the cast of the English version of Cowboy Bebop. Either that or it's some very good impersonators (it's not) (You should watch it if you never have, amazing) After realizing who the voice actors were, the games overall feel and tone took on a whole new meaning to me. Your character is Spike. Negatives. A community hell-bent on saying the entire game is ruined on a few added features. At one point the dev’s tried to put online DRM into the game, and it seemed like that’s when the brigaiding of negative reviews began (coming from reddit) The feature was removed, but the community is still jilted. This is perhaps the biggest negative about the game. You might not even buy it at $4 bucks, because of the bad reviews.  OK now for some actual negatives.  * Angry Video Game Nerd professes his love for “Megaman X” because of how the first stage teaches you how to play the game. I don’t think there’s enough of that in Miner Wars. The first level *should* be a little slower. Instead it’s “BAM!”, and the player has no time to learn the controls, or how to use the weapons properly. * Too destructable sometimes. There are key terminals/checkpoints that need to be used at places in the game that can get destroyed by NPC fire.  *Multiplayer is a ghosttown * Development has somewhat ceased.   Advice to Keen. You’re doing good on your other games. You *might* want to revisit this one. Maybe tie it into the Space Engineers universe.  Advice to gamers. Don’t expect this to be anything more than a 3d platformer get key open door 6dof game. If you enjoy the genre, the game is worth it.
